newsitem.title: SPAIN: Spain to seek help of EU on digital TV problems.
newsitem.headline: Spain to seek help of EU on digital TV problems.

text.p: Spain's Development Ministry said on Thursday it would seek the European Commission's advice on problems in its controversial digital TV market.
But the European Commission already started legal proceedings against Spain on Thursday, saying a Spanish law requiring a specific type of decoding technology could restrict free trade.
Canal Plus' Canalsatelite Digital complained to the Commission in February that the Spanish law on decoders effectively bans the pay-television channel from using its technology in Spain.
The Spanish ministry said it would respond to the European Commission proceedings when it received notice of them in writing.

Meanwhile, the ministry said it would seek the Commission's advice on what it should do if companies which use incompatible decoders do not reach an agreement to convert their decoders to the Spanish standard. It will also ask what leeway member states have to resolve the question.
The Spanish government imposed a law approved at the end of January requiring different digital TV companies to have compatible decoders.
Unless otherwise agreed between digital TV companies, this law requires technology known as the multicrypt system be adopted.
However, the only Spanish platform currently in operation, Canal Plus' Canalsatelite Digital, is based on the simulcrypt system.
"The Commission of (European Justice) Tribunal will have to decide if the decoders are or are not legal," the ministry said.

Telecommunications operators Telefonica de Espana and state-television RTVE are planning to launch a rival digital package Via Digital in September using the multicrypt system, prompting allegations that the government is giving them time to get the project ready.
